awd_titl_txt: CANSec: The Central Area Networking and Security Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
As the world becomes more connected every day, the topic of information security becomes more important.  While researchers and students from universities across the nation are conducting important research and outreach that results in advances in information security, the impact of these efforts could be widened at a forum to share research findings, best practices, foster collaboration, and provide a forum for students to interact with other scientists and practitioners in the field. The proposed project from the University of Kansas requests funds to provide travel support for students attending the Central Area Networking and Security Workshop (CANSec). The CANSec Workshop is an annual regional workshop that aims to bring together researchers and practitioners in security and networking related fields across the Great Plains region. Since its inception, eleven workshops have been successfully held. The workshop will offer a variety of sessions including keynote talks, research presentations, posters, industrial/academic panels, and cyber defense competitions. It provides students a chance to present their ideas and research to other students, faculty, and professionals in a constructive environment, and to learn and practice cyber defense skills in a real-world scenario.

The objective of the Central Area Networking and Security Workshop (CANSec) is to provide a regular forum for researchers and students across several Midwestern states (Kansas, Missouri, Colorado, Iowa, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Texas, and Indiana) to present research and educational activities, and to promote interactions and collaborations. This grant would provide travel support for students attending CANSec, so they can interact with peers and faculty from across the region. The CANSec organizing team strives to keep low costs for the attendees to accommodate more student participants and a broader audience. The CANSec workshop also promotes the development and collaboration in information security research and education in the Great Plains region with several EPSCoR states including Kansas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Nebraska.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Kansas received $20,000 to provide travel grants for students attending CANSec: The Central Area Networking and Security Workshops:  CANSec 2018 hosted by The Kansas State University on October 27 to 28; CANSec 2019 hosted by The Iowa State University on October 26; CANSec 2021 (fully virtual) hosted by University of Missouri  on Nov 13 to 14; CANSec 2022 hosted by the Wichita State University on October 22; and CANSec 2023 hosted by the University of Kansas on October 14th, 2023.

A total of 82 student-trips were supported by the grant. In particular, 26 students were supported in CANSec 2018, 21 students were supported in CANSec 2019, 19 students were supported in CANSec 2022, and 16 students were supported in CANSec 2023. Among the awardees, 34 were oral or poster presenters. 24 awards (29%) were given to students of underrepresented groups.

The CANSec workshop is an annual event that brings together researchers and practitioners in security- and networking-related fields across the central area of the US. As of 2024, 17 CANSec (formerly KanSec) workshops have been hosted by various universities in the central area of the US. The workshop aims to promote interactions and collaborations among scholars and students and between academia and industry. It offers a variety of sessions including keynote talks, research oral and poster presentations, industrial-academia panels, and cyber defense competitions. With the help of the travel grant, students got the chance to attend the workshop, to listen to keynote talks and panels, and present their ideas and research to other students, faculty, and professionals in a constructive environment, and to learn and practice cyber defense skills in a real-world scenario.

The CANSec workshop also promotes the development and collaboration in information security research and education in the Great Plains region with several EPSCoR states including Kansas, Oklahoma, Iowa, Arkansas, and Nebraska. The CANSec organizing team strives to keep low costs for the attendees to accommodate more student participants and a broader audience. The organizing committee of each workshop event selected outstanding students for the NSF travel awards, which covered a part of their travel costs for attending the workshop.


Last Modified: 01/13/2025
Modified by: Bo Luo
